questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of increased flow and duration of her menses. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 5 days with normal flow. They now last 8–9 days, and the flow is heavy with the passage of clots. During this period, she has also had lower abdominal pain that begins 2–3 days prior to the onset of menses and lasts for 2 days after the end of menses. She has three children. Her mother died of endometrial cancer at the age of 61 years. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a tender, uniformly enlarged, boggy uterus consistent in size with an 8-week gestation. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benign smooth muscle tumors within the uterine wall (myometrium) are characteristic of fibroids, which may also cause heavy menstrual bleeding. However, rather than manifesting with a uniformly enlarged uterus, fibroids tend to result in an irregularly enlarged and firm uterus. Fibroids that are especially large or numerous may cause constant pelvic pressure and pain rather than isolated menstrual pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Pedunculated endometrial masses (a type of uterine polyp) are endometrial overgrowths that can cause heavy menstrual bleeding if they are highly vascularized. However, uterine polyps do not cause symmetrical enlargement of the uterus.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant proliferation of trophoblasts is seen in choriocarcinoma, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic tenderness, and an enlarged uterus in women who recently had a hydatidiform mole or pregnancy. This patient's urine pregnancy test was negative.
Image Description:

GTD is a group of diseases that originate in the placenta and typically result from abnormal fertilization of the ovum. Complete and partial moles may develop malignant traits and become invasive. Choriocarcinoma may be preceded by hydatidiform moles (50% of cases), ectopic pregnancy or miscarriages, or normal pregnancy.

Theca lutein cysts result from exaggerated stimulation of the theca interna cells of the ovarian follicles due to excessive amounts of beta-hCG.

D) CORRECT:

Ectopic endometrial tissue within the myometrium is characteristic of uterine adenomyosis, which has a peak incidence between 40 and 50 years of age. The ectopic endometrial tissue induces hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the surrounding myometrium and results in a symmetrically enlarged uterus similar to a uterus in pregnancy. Secretions from ectopic glands within the myometrium cause pain and cramping, which become worse during menses.

The definitive diagnosis of adenomyosis requires histopathologic examination of a hysterectomy specimen, and although the diagnosis could be further supported by MRI and uterine biopsy, these tools would not provide any extra benefits for treatment. Hysterectomy is the treatment of choice in severe disease.
Image Description:

MRI pelvis (T2-weighted; sagittal plane)

Uterine enlargement accompanied by diffuse, predominantly hypointense widening of the junctional zone is seen. Multiple punctate high-intensity myometrial foci are visible within the uterine wall, demonstrating scattered foci of ectopic endometrium (examples indicated by arrowheads).

The findings are characteristic of uterine adenomyosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue is seen in endometrial carcinoma, the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US, which can also manifest with heavy menstrual bleeding. Though this patient has a positive family history, this diagnosis is still unlikely because endometrial cancer usually does not cause uterine enlargement in the early stage, the average age at diagnosis is 70 years, and she has no other risk factors (e.g., nulliparity, metabolic syndrome, history of increased estrogen exposure).

F) INCORRECT:

Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue with no evidence of atypia or invasion on endometrial biopsy is characteristic of endometrial hyperplasia, which can also present with abnormal uterine bleeding. However, endometrial hyperplasia is much more common in nulliparous women and does not result in a symmetrically enlarged uterus.

G) INCORRECT:

Endometritis can also cause abnormal uterine bleeding but is not associated with an enlarged uterus. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of endometritis, such as fever, constant lower abdominal pain and tenderness, abnormal discharge, and a history of sexually transmitted infections.

H) INCORRECT:

Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and/or cervix are found in patients with endometriosis, a condition that can also cause dysmenorrhea. However, in patients with endometriosis, the uterus is not enlarged. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of endometriosis, such as rectovaginal tenderness or dyspareunia.
questions.hint: Regular, heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea in a multiparous woman with a uniformly enlarged and tender uterus suggest a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with a year of progressively heavier menstrual bleeding and worsening dysmenorrhea. She denies any history of abnormal uterine bleeding before this year. Her last Pap smear was normal, and she has no known reproductive tract infections or surgeries. Physical examination reveals a uniformly enlarged, tender uterus without distinct masses (see report).
Pelvic ultrasound: Diffusely bulky uterus with heterogeneous myometrium; no well-defined focal lesions
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intramural leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that present as well-circumscribed, hypoechoic masses within the myometrium on imaging. The ultrasound findings of a diffusely bulky uterus with heterogeneous myometrium and no discrete lesions suggest a diffuse process, not localized nodular growths typical of leiomyomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis involves ectopic endometrial tissue on pelvic structures, causing cyclical pelvic pain and sometimes infertility. It does not typically result in a uniformly enlarged uterus. Instead, it produces localized lesions or adnexal masses, unlike the diffuse myometrial heterogeneity seen in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Adenomyosis involves endometrial glandular tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged uterus with heterogeneous myometrial texture on ultrasound. This condition causes heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea due to localized inflammation and smooth muscle hypertrophy. The diffuse uterine enlargement without distinct focal lesions differentiates it from conditions with discrete masses. Adenomyosis is common in women in their forties, presenting with progressive symptoms without prior surgeries or infections.

Key learning point: Adenomyosis is characterized by a bulky, tender uterus and is associated with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, distinguishing it from other conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids.

D) INCORRECT:

Endometrial hyperplasia involves increased proliferation of the endometrial lining, often due to unopposed estrogen exposure, and presents with abnormal uterine bleeding. It is associated with focal endometrial thickening, not a diffusely enlarged uterus with heterogeneous myometrium, as seen here.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with progressively heavy menstrual bleeding and worsening dysmenorrhea for the past year. Her pelvic pain often intensifies midway through her menses. She has had three full-term pregnancies and denies any recent medication changes. On pelvic examination, her uterus is symmetrically enlarged and mildly tender, with no discrete adnexal masses palpable (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Hemoglobin
108 g/L
120 - 160 g/L



Transvaginal ultrasound: Uniformly bulky uterus without focal lesions
Endometrial biopsy: No abnormal cells

Which of the following best explains her clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Multiple uterine leiomyomas typically present as discrete, well-circumscribed masses, causing an irregularly enlarged uterus on examination and imaging. The symmetrically enlarged uterus and uniformly bulky appearance on transvaginal ultrasound in this patient do not align with the heterogeneous appearance of fibroids.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis involves ectopic endometrial tissue outside the uterus, causing dysmenorrhea and pelvic pain. The uterus is usually normal in size, and the condition is characterized by ovarian endometriomas or peritoneal implants. The uniformly bulky uterus and absence of discrete adnexal masses do not align with endometriosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometrial hyperplasia, caused by unopposed estrogen exposure, leads to a thickened endometrium and abnormal uterine bleeding. It does not typically cause a uniformly bulky uterus or significant dysmenorrhea. The endometrial biopsy shows no abnormal cells, and the ultrasound findings do not support this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Adenomyosis is characterized by ectopic endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium, leading to a diffusely enlarged and tender uterus. It commonly presents in multiparous women in their forties with progressive heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, often worsening midway through the menstrual cycle. The uterus is symmetrically bulky without discrete masses, as confirmed by transvaginal ultrasound. Cyclic hormonal stimulation of ectopic endometrial tissue causes inflammation and myometrial hypertrophy, resulting in bleeding and pain. Chronic heavy bleeding can lead to anemia, as indicated by the reduced hemoglobin level.

Key learning point: Adenomyosis is characterized by a tender, diffusely enlarged uterus, and is associated with secondary dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, with a normal endometrial biopsy.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 4, comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of painful, heavy menses. Menses previously occurred at regular 28-day intervals and lasted 3 days with normal flow. They now last 7–8 days and the flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Pelvic examination shows a tender, uniformly enlarged, flaccid uterus consistent in size with an 8-week gestation. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Endometrial tissue within the uterine wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pedunculated endometrial masses (a type of uterine polyp) are endometrial overgrowths that can cause menorrhagia if they are highly vascularized. However, uterine polyps do not cause symmetrical enlargement of the uterus.

B) CORRECT:

Ectopic endometrial glandular tissue within the uterine wall (myometrium) is characteristic of uterine adenomyosis, which has a peak incidence in women 40–50 years of age. The ectopic endometrial tissue induces hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the surrounding myometrium and results in a symmetrically enlarged uterus that is similar to a uterus in pregnancy. Secretions from ectopic glands within the myometrium cause pain and cramping, which become worse during menses.

The definitive diagnosis of adenomyosis requires histological examination of a hysterectomy specimen. Although MRI and uterine biopsy could further support the diagnosis, these tools would not provide any additional benefits for treatment. Hormonal treatment with GnRH agonists or oral contraceptives may provide symptomatic relief. Hysterectomy is the only definitive therapy and the preferred treatment in severe disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant transformation of endometrial tissue is seen in endometrial carcinoma, the most common cancer of the female genital tract in the US, which can also present with menorrhagia. However, endometrial carcinoma is unlikely because it usually does not cause uterine enlargement in early stages, the average age at diagnosis is 70 years, and this patient has no risk factors (e.g., nulliparity, metabolic syndrome, history of increased estrogen exposure).

D) INCORRECT:

Abnormal thickening of endometrial tissue with no evidence of atypia or invasion on endometrial biopsy is characteristic for endometrial hyperplasia, which can also present with abnormal uterine bleeding. However, endometrial hyperplasia is much more common in nulliparous women and does not involve a symmetrically enlarged uterus.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometriotic cell implants in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, and/or cervix are found in patients with endometriosis, a condition that can also cause dysmenorrhea. However, in endometriosis, the uterus is not enlarged and this patient lacks other features caused by ectopic endometrial tissue, e.g., rectovaginal tenderness and dyspareunia.

F) INCORRECT:

Benign smooth muscle tumors within the uterine wall (myometrium) are characteristic for fibroids, which can also cause menorrhagia. However, rather than manifesting with a uniformly enlarged uterus, fibroids tend to manifest with an irregularly enlarged and firm uterus. Fibroids that are especially large or numerous may cause constant pelvic pressure and pain rather than menstrual pain exclusively. They are much more common in nulliparous women.
questions.hint: Menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea in a multiparous woman with a diffusely enlarged and tender uterus suggest adenomyosis.
